Figure 1:Spectral analysisof SDXL (Left) and SD3.5 (Right) VAE latents (128√ó128128128128{\times}128128 √ó 128) for different diffusion timesteps.
Vertical lines mark frequency boundaries for lower resolutions; frequencies to the right are not present at lower scale latents.
Noise masks high frequencies, suggesting that latent DMs can operate at lower latent resolutions for high noise levels.

Figure 3:SwDsampling.Starting from noise at the low scales1subscriptùë†1s_{1}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the model gradually increases resolution viamultistep stochastic sampling.
At each step, the previous prediction at the scalesi‚àí1subscriptùë†ùëñ1s_{i-1}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTis upscaled and noised according to thetimestep schedule,tisubscriptùë°ùëñt_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
Then, the generator predicts a clean image at the current scalesisubscriptùë†ùëñs_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Figure 4:SD3.5 generates cropped images at low-resolutions (256√ó256256256256{\times}256256 √ó 256), while SDXL does not produce meaningful images at all.SwDis able to perform successful distillation for such cases and corrects these limitations.
